Literature Review: High-dimensional survival analysis has become a cornerstone in the era of precision medicine, where the integration of time-to-event outcomes with high-throughput covariates necessitates advanced statistical and machine learning methodologies. Traditional survival regression models, such as the Cox proportional hazards model, face significant challenges in this context, primarily due to the curse of dimensionality and the risk of overfitting. This literature review explores the evolution of methods designed to navigate these challenges, focusing on feature selection, survival prognostication, and the application of machine learning techniques. The advent of high-dimensional data in medical research has spurred the development of novel approaches that extend beyond classical survival analysis. Feature selection techniques, such as LASSO (Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator) and its variants, have been pivotal in identifying relevant predictors from a vast pool of covariates. These methods not only enhance model interpretability but also improve prediction accuracy by mitigating overfitting. Recent studies have demonstrated the efficacy of LASSO in high-dimensional survival analysis, showcasing its ability to select a sparse set of predictors while maintaining model performance. Beyond feature selection, machine learning approaches have revolutionized survival prediction by leveraging complex algorithms capable of capturing non-linear relationships and interactions among predictors. Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), for instance, have been adapted for survival analysis, offering a flexible framework for modeling time-to-event data. The integration of ANNs with survival analysis has been shown to outperform traditional methods in various settings, particularly in the presence of high-dimensional data. Moreover, the application of machine learning extends to more complex scenarios, such as competing risks analysis, where multiple events of interest may preclude the occurrence of each other. Advanced machine learning models, including random survival forests and gradient boosting machines, have been developed to address these complexities, providing robust tools for survival prediction in the presence of competing risks. The Boston Lung Cancer Survival Cohort study serves as a prime example of the application of these methods in cancer epidemiology. By employing high-dimensional survival analysis techniques, researchers have been able to uncover intricate mechanisms underlying lung cancer progression and survival, paving the way for personalized treatment strategies. In conclusion, the field of high-dimensional survival analysis has witnessed significant advancements, driven by the need to analyze complex datasets in precision medicine. The integration of feature selection techniques and machine learning algorithms has provided powerful tools for survival prediction, offering insights into disease mechanisms and informing clinical decision-making. As the volume and complexity of biomedical data continue to grow, further innovations in high-dimensional survival analysis are anticipated, promising to enhance our understanding of disease progression and improve patient outcomes.
